summary: The Select Committee on Assassinations (SCA) was a U.S. House of Representatives committee established to investigate the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr. The documents primarily consist of payroll certifications and reports detailing the committee's staff, their positions, salaries, and employment dates. These records span from early 1977 to late 1978, indicating the period of active investigation and operation of the committee. The documents highlight the administrative and financial aspects of the committee's functioning, providing insights into the personnel involved and the resources allocated to the investigation.
significance: The Select Committee on Assassinations played a crucial role in re-examining the circumstances surrounding the assassinations of JFK and Martin Luther King Jr. While the documents provided focus on the committee's internal operations and personnel, the committee's broader significance lies in its efforts to investigate these pivotal events in American history and provide a comprehensive report on its findings.
